data.title: (#90) Emperor Maximilian and Empress Carlotta of Mexico: A pair of Austrian silver dessert stands, Franz Schiffer & Sohn, Vienna, 1857
data.text:
Description

height 22 1/2 in.

57cm

the strongly modeled baluster stands decorated with matted acanthus, engraved with a foliate cypher under a crown

Provenance

The monogram reads FC conjoined under an imperial crown for Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian Joseph of Austria (1832-1867) and his wife whom he married in 1857, Princess Charlotte of Belgium (1840-1927), later Emperor Maximilian and Empress Carlotta of Mexico.

Condition

a few very small dings, otherwise very good condition, good size

In response to your inquiry, we are pleased to provide you with a general report of the condition of the property described above. Since we are not professional conservators or restorers, we urge you to consult with a restorer or conservator of your choice who will be better able to provide a detailed, professional report. Prospective buyers should inspect each lot to satisfy themselves as to condition and must understand that any statement made by Sotheby's is merely a subjective qualified opinion.

NOTWITHSTANDING THIS REPORT OR ANY DISCUSSIONS CONCERNING CONDITION OF A LOT, ALL LOTS ARE OFFERED AND SOLD "AS IS" IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CONDITIONS OF SALE PRINTED IN THE CATALOGUE.

Catalogue Note

After the marriage, Archduke Ferdinand Max first served as Viceroy of Lombardy-Venetia, but he was removed by Emperor Franz Josef for his liberal views. He was then approached my Mexican monarchists, and in 1864 the couple became Emperor Maximilian and Empress Carlotte of Mexico. The Emperor was executed by firing squad in 1867, but Carlotta survived for another 60 years, residing in Trieste and Belgium but living increasingly in her own head.

The firm of Franz Schiffer & Sohn were named Imperial Court gold- and silversmiths in 1846; Franz Schiffer died in 1854, so these were made under his son Eduard.
